translation: The burden of Nineveh. The book of the vision of Nahum the Elkoshite.
A jealous and avenging God is the LORD; the LORD is avenging and full of wrath; the LORD takes vengeance on his adversaries and reserves it for his enemies.
The LORD is slow to anger and great in power, yet the guilty he will by no means clear. The LORD—his way is in the whirlwind and in the storm, and the clouds are the dust of his feet.
He rebukes the sea and makes it dry, and he dries up all the rivers; Bashan and Carmel languish, and the blossom of Lebanon withers.
The mountains quake before Him, and the hills melt away; the earth is lifted up at His presence, the world and all who dwell in it.
Who can stand before His indignation, and who can arise in the fierceness of His anger? His wrath is poured out like fire, and the rocks are broken asunder by Him.
The LORD is good, a stronghold in the day of trouble; and He knows those who take refuge in Him.
But with an overwhelming flood he will make a full end of her place, and darkness shall pursue his enemies.
What do you devise against the LORD? He is making a full end; distress shall not rise up a second time.
For though they are entangled like thorns, and as their drink they are drunk, they shall be consumed like fully dry stubble.
From you has come forth one who devises evil against the LORD, a counselor of worthlessness.
Thus says the LORD: Though they are at full strength, and likewise many, yet so shall they be cut down, and he shall pass away. Though I have afflicted you, I will afflict you no more.
And now I will break his yoke from off you, and I will tear your bonds asunder.

And the LORD has commanded concerning you: No more shall your name be sown; out of the house of your god I will cut off carved image and molten idol. I will make your grave, for you are of no account.

Behold upon the mountains the feet of him who brings good tidings, who proclaims peace. Keep your feasts, O Judah, fulfill your vows; for the worthless one shall no more pass through you; he is utterly cut off.
The scatterer has come up against your face; guard the fortress, watch the road, strengthen your loins, make your power very mighty.
For the LORD restores the majesty of Jacob, as the majesty of Israel; for plunderers have plundered them, and have ruined their vine branches.
The shield of his mighty men is reddened, the valiant men are clothed in scarlet; the chariots flash with steel in the day he prepares them, and the cypresses are brandished.
The chariots rage in the streets, they rush to and fro in the broad ways; their appearance is like torches, they run to and fro like lightnings.
He remembers his nobles; they stumble in their going, they hasten to her wall, and the shelter is prepared.
The gates of the rivers are opened, and the palace melts away.
And it is fixed: she is uncovered, she is carried away, and her maidens moan like the voice of doves, beating upon their breasts.
And Nineveh is like a pool of water from her days; yet they flee. “Stand, stand,” but none turns back.
Plunder the silver, plunder the gold; there is no end to the treasure, abundance of every precious vessel.
Empty, and desolate, and laid waste; and the heart melts, and knees tremble, and anguish is in all loins, and the faces of them all gather pallor.
Where is the den of lions, and the pasture of the young lions, where the lion walked, the lioness, and the lion’s whelp, and none made them afraid?
The lion tore enough for his cubs, and strangled for his lionesses, and filled his caves with prey, and his dens with torn flesh.

Behold, I am against you, declares the LORD of hosts, and I will burn your chariots in smoke, and the sword shall devour your young lions; and I will cut off your prey from the earth, and the voice of your messengers shall no more be heard.
Woe to the bloody city, all of it full of lies and plunder; the prey does not depart.
The sound of the whip, and the sound of the rattling wheel, and the galloping horse, and the bounding chariot.
The horseman charging, and the flashing sword and the glittering spear; and a multitude of slain, and a heavy heap of corpses, and there is no end of the bodies; they stumble over their dead.
Because of the multitude of the harlotries of the harlot, comely and full of grace, mistress of sorceries, who sells nations by her whoredoms, and families by her witchcrafts.
Behold, I am against you, declares the LORD of hosts; and I will lift up your skirts over your face, and I will let the nations see your nakedness, and the kingdoms your shame.
And I will cast abominations upon you, and make you vile, and will set you as a spectacle.
And it shall come to pass, all who look upon you shall flee from you and say, “Nineveh is laid waste; who will lament for her?” From where shall I seek comforters for you?
Are you better than No-amon, that sat by the Nile, with waters round about her, whose rampart was the sea, whose wall was from the sea?
Cush was her strength, and Egypt without end; Put and the Libyans were among your helpers.

She also went into exile, she went into captivity; her little ones too were dashed in pieces at the head of every street; and for her honored men they cast lots, and all her great ones were bound in chains.
You also shall be drunken; you shall be hidden. You also shall seek a stronghold because of the enemy.
All your strongholds are fig trees with first-ripe figs; if they are shaken, they fall into the mouth of the eater.
Behold, your people in your midst are women; the gates of your land are opened wide to your enemies; fire has consumed your bars.
Draw for yourself water for the siege; strengthen your fortresses. Go into the clay and tread the mortar; take hold of the brick mold.
There shall the fire devour you; the sword shall cut you off; it shall eat you up like the locust. Multiply yourself like the locust, multiply yourself like the great locust.
You have multiplied your merchants above the stars of heaven; the locust strips and flies away.
Your princes are like the locusts, and your scribes like swarms of young locusts that encamp in the hedges in the day of cold; the sun rises, and they flee, and the place where they are is not known.
Your shepherds slumber, O king of Assyria; your nobles lie down. Your people are scattered upon the mountains, and there is no one to gather them.
There is no easing of your fracture; your wound is grievous. All who hear the report of you clap their hands over you, for upon whom has not your evil passed continually?
